rows.name: Math Talk – Early & Often

block1_text.eng:
**Math Talk is Important!:** Math Talk involves discussing with a child in an informal way the math ideas that normally occur silently in an adult's thoughts. Studies show that the amount of Math Talk a family does is strongly predictive of a child's math preparation when entering school, and that in turn is highly predictive of a child's success throughout all their school years, in all subjects! This simple habit can make a lifetime of difference!

**Exposure:** During these early years, it is all about exposure! The child is being exposed to a wide array of experiences and is discovering patterns in everything they sense. As part of exposing this child to the world, expose them to math words and ideas.

**Start early:** Start Math Talk at four to six months old, even before the child seems to understand what you're saying. A young child is a sponge who is getting more from words than you realize.

block2_text.eng: **Point and describe:** Point at things the child interacts with and describe them with words involving numbers, shapes, colors, and relationships. If you are dealing with a small set of things, count them out loud to the child.

block3_text.eng:
There is much more to math than just numbers. Build up this vocabulary and concepts to help your child develop mathematically. It will also give a big boost to helping your a read and talk about the world.

* Describe. Talk about sizes, colors, textures, shapes, softness, wetness, hotness, brightness, and more. Naming and describing properties is essential for comparing them and discovering patterns.
* Compare. Bigger, smaller, tallest, widest, more, less, same, ... 
* Use position words. Over, under, between, near, far, above, ...
* Patterns and sequences in space and time. Refer to the order of things as first, second, third, and last. Talk about what just happened, what is about to happen, and things happening today. Talk about patterns in designs you see.
* Count things out loud and say numbers to refer to quantities.
* Use measurement words. Use words for length, area, weight, and volume whenever you are describing sizes.

rows.name: Math Talk at Home

block1_text.eng:
Household routines and activities done together are opportunities for mathematical conversations with a child.

**Putting things away:** Talk about which things belong together. Do things that are the same shape go together? Is there a special place for round things or triangular things?

**Clothes:** When sorting clothes, talk about colors, shapes, and sizes.

**Going to sleep and getting up:** These times lend themselves to discussing doing things in order, and practicing words like first, second, third, last, and next.

**Discuss as you read:** Storytime is a wonderful chance to do math with your child in a cozy setting. Talk about the characters and the things in the pictures.

block2_text.eng:
**Counting:** When the child gets older, count together by pointing or ask the child to point to things you describe.

**Food:** Whether putting food away, cooking food, or setting things out for mealtime, there are many opportunities for math. Different kinds of food should be put away in particular places – this is a good time for relationship words like inside, under, and over.

Cooking involves measuring quantities, talking about lengths of time, and describing the desired result for the food. Setting things out for mealtime involves setting out the appropriate number of things so that each person gets what they need.

**Playing with objects:** Compare objects when constructing things for play or other uses. Which one is taller? Can you make one thing taller, wider, bigger, or the same as the other? Describe and compare the sizes, numbers, and colors of things you have or that are in pictures.

rows.name: Math Talk Out & About

block1_text.eng:
**Shapes:** You might see a circle in a design in a building and ask the child to point out other circles they see, such as the circles in a traffic light. Traffic signs and shop signs provide a great supply of shapes you can describe and name.

**Traveling:** There are many mathematical things to talk about as you travel. Ask about bigger, smaller, thinner, and wider things such as buildings, windows, trees, and people. Which things are closer than others, and which things are farther away?

**Counting in a store:** Talk about how many apples you need, and count them out as you pick them out. Count the people in line in front of you, and compare that to the length of the other lines.

block2_text.eng:
Point out the shapes of fruit or pictures on food boxes. Talk about how some things come in boxes, and other things come in round bottles. You might need something on a high shelf, or something on a low shelf. There is so much to describe and compare!

**In a park:** Count the children, the number of structures or trees, or anything else. Comment about where there is more of one thing than another.

block3_text.eng: **On the swings:** Pushing a child on something that swings or sways back and forth is a perfect opportunity to count with a child. With each push, count “1, 2, 3, 4, 5.” After the child starts learning how to count to 5, counting down from 5 is also a good idea. Start or end at 0 sometimes.

block4_text.eng: Point out the circles, curves, straight lines, triangles, and rectangles in the park. Talk about how some things are over, under, between, or on top of other things.

rows.name: Math Talk – Describe & Compare

block1_text.eng: **There is important math beyond numbers:** Describing and comparing things is an important part of helping a child learn early mathematics. When children do mathematics, they use ideas about properties of objects to help them work with those objects, such as in grouping them or finding patterns with them. These skills will also help your child when it comes time to start learning to read.

block2_text.eng: **Point, describe, and compare:** Wherever you are, get in the habit of pointing at things that catch your or the child's attention, and then describing them. Take the opportunity to compare those things to other things to help the descriptions be more meaningful. Talk about how two things are the same or how they are different.

block3_text.eng: Don't confuse early exposure with teaching. A child will put together the patterns from their experiences as they are developmentally ready. For example, you can't teach your child to count to 5 by explaining it to them – you can only expose them to your counting over and over again until it starts making sense to them. Never be impatient or push them to understand it more quickly – they have a lot to learn and they will naturally want to make sense of it all.

block4_text.eng:
**Searching game:** Make a game of searching for objects around where you are. Use the game to practice concepts that your child is learning, such as color, size (large, medium, small), weight (heavy, light), quantity, and relationship (inside, on top of, below).

One of you says to the other that they see something that is round on top of something that is brown. The other person tries to discover what it is. If they have trouble finding it, more clues are given.

rows.name: Math Talk – Counting

block1_text.eng:
**Counting, Numbers, and Quantities:** This invovles several things to work on at the same time, so it can be more complicated for a child than what you might think.

* Counting forward and backward, including 0 sometimes
* Learning the numbers
* Learning quantities

**Repeating the sequence:** At first, your counting will cause the child to start repeating the numbers in sequence. Don't be surprised if they leave out some of the numbers or they say the numbers in the wrong order. If they make errors, don't make a big deal out of it; simply say the count correctly and move on. This is all part of the process and they will eventually learn the numbers in the correct order.

**Count down sometimes:** Counting down will help your child understand the sequence. This helps keep it from being a meaningless sequence of sounds. Do this almost any time you would have counted up. For example, if you have three apples you want to remove, count down from three after you take away each apple.

**Include 0 sometimes:** Start your counting at 0 sometimes to help 0 become an accepted number and quantity. You can also count down to 0. Counting down to 0 is great for events that are about to happen, say in five seconds. You can count down to 0 and then say "Blastoff" or something similar.

**Understanding quantities:** It is obvious to an adult that if you count a collection of things, say four pebbles, that when you count "1, 2, 3, 4" the last number you say is the size of the quantity of things you have. The child is learning several things about counting and quantities. They are gaining an understanding of quantities. They are learning that when they count something they do a 1-to-1 correspondence between the things and the numbers they're saying. They are learning that it doesn't matter in which order you count things. And finally, they are learning the "last number is the size" rule. Be patient and remember that there is no rush.

**Count everything:** There are so many things to count. Count chairs, steps to go a short distance, food items, people in line, people in a group, furniture around a table or in a room, arms, legs, and who knows what else. Whenever you find yourself mentally counting something, count it out loud in front of your child.

rows.name: Math Talk – Point, Describe, Ask

block1_text.eng:
**Responding:** Once a child is able to respond to what you say, that will allow you to start asking questions. Your "Point and Describe" Math Talk wlll now become "Point, Describe, and Ask." Even before a child can say words, they will start to respond nonverbally to you as they begin to make sense of your words.

**Ask questions:** Use this new level of communication to make it clearer which ideas a child understands. "Where is the bird?" or "Where is the ball? makes it clear if your child knows what a bird or ball is. Similarly, "Point to the tree." or "Point to a car." works for those two concepts.

**Handling mistakes:** Ask all kinds of questions. Ask which of two things is bigger or smaller. Ask where you are walking to. Ask where something belongs. All these questions are opportunities for your child to express their understanding and for you to clear up any misconceptions. If your child points to the wrong thing or picks up the wrong thing, simply point out the right thing and don't try to explain their mistake to them.

**Do this while reading:** Now you can add asking questions to your pointing and describing as you read a story. Point to pictures in the story and ask the same questions you would ask about the things around you.

**Simple riddles:** Play games with your child's new skill and have fun with it.  Have fun unraveling puzzles together such as: "There is something red under something blue. Where is it?"

rows.name: Dialogic Reading – Preverbal

block1_text.eng: There is a big difference between just reading to a child and discussing what is going on for each page of a story. Reading interactively and having a dialogue as you read is called **Dialogic Reading.** Not only does this provide deeper engagement with the story, it also gives opportunities to explore concepts and vocabulary that you choose to connect with the story. It also gives the child more involvement and agency with the story telling.

block2_text.eng:
The types of dialogues you have depend very much on a child's level of development. Some of these considerations are similar to what you should consider when doing Math Talk with a child. It is often tempting to rush these development levels, but they take time and it is silly to ask about ideas that a child cannot relate to yet.

These first two levels are for **Preverbal Children.**

block3_text.eng: Although this will be a one-sided dialogue, it lays the foundation for future conversations. It is all about exposure at this level. **Point at and Describe** simple objects and characters in the story. When you point at things, name them and describe them by talking about properties like shape, color, relationships, and quantities. With more and more exposure, the child will start to pick up the concepts on their own timetable.

block4_text.eng: You are now able to **Point at, Describe, and Ask** about simple story elements and objects in the illustrations. The dialogue takes place by having the child point at the objects they understand but don’t have the words for yet. You can ask questions like “Where is the ball?” or give prompts like “Point at the red toy.

block5_text.eng: The next three levels involve true dialogues between you and a verbal child. These will be discussed in the next topic.

rows.name: Dialogic Reading – Verbal

block1_text.eng:
The previous topic on early reading with a child focused on Dialogic Reading with a preverbal child. Reading interactively and having a dialogue as you read is called **Dialogic Reading.** Doing this with a verbal child produces an interaction that is truly a dialogue.

Here are the three classical levels of dialogic reading. As before, it will be tempting to rush these development levels, but they take time. For example, do not ask about where a story is going or how a character is feeling if the child is just beginning to identify apples and red objects.

block2_text.eng: As your child begins to understand and say words, mix in simple questions. Freely help with answers as needed. If you point and say "Is this red?" and they don't know, supply the answer. If you say "Count the apples" and your child does not know how, point and count the apples with them "one, two, three." Ask simple, basic questions (“Is that a cat?” “What color is the tree?” “What is the dog doing?”) as you point to things on the current page of the story.

block3_text.eng: Begin to ask questions with less definite and simple answers. Questions such as “What is happening to the bird?” and “Do you think that is a fair way to split things up? invite broader answers and discussions. Expand on the child’s response to create further questions and discussion ideas. Fight the temptation to let your follow up questions slip into the next level.

block4_text.eng: These questions may discuss the narrative of the story, such as what has happened so far or what will happen next, or they may relate back to the child’s life or world, such as do you like it when it rains. Also ask questions about a character’s inner life, such as what the character is feeling and have they ever felt like that. At this level, there should be much more give and take, and the child should be encouraged to put questions of their own into the dialogue.

rows.name: Properties & Grouping

block1_text.eng: **Properties are where everything starts:** Understanding that objects have properties is the beginning of mathematics, and more generally an understanding of the world. It is why very early training in math is so central to a child's success in all areas of learning.

block2_text.eng:
**Many types of properties:** There are a wide variety of types of properties. The listing below is just the start.

* Color and shape – color names, round, flat, square
* Size – large, small, medium, larger, largest
* Texture – rough, smooth, wet, dry, pointed, grooved
* Sound – loud, soft, louder, 
* Order – first, second, third, last, next
* Spatial – above, inside, low, higher, around

**Properties for multiple objects:** Not only do individual objects have properties, but they can have properties that describe relationships between more than one object. There are basic comparison words for many of these properties: larger, largest, louder, and loudest. There are spatial relationship words such as under, over, next to, above, and inside.

block3_accord.eng: Practice: Ask for things by Property

block3_text.eng: Practice using properties by asking the child to bring you something with that property. You could ask "Please bring me something that is red." for example. As a child gets better at this, make the requests more complicated by combining more than one property – "Find a round wooden thing."

block4_text.eng: Practice grouping things with the same property. If the child has a collection of objects, ask to have all the round things put to one side.

block5_text.eng:
**A circle for each property:** Make this visible by drawing a big circle and having all the things that have a particular property put in that circle. For example, you could have all the things with a hole in them put in the circle.

As this becomes easy for your child, use two circles that overlap – one circle could be for triangles, the other for things with holes, and the common area to the two circles would be for triangles with holes.

rows.name: Same & Different

block1_text.eng: **Comparing:** Help your students better understand properties by using comparing and contrasting. This is a very important activity that helps remove misunderstandings and deepens awareness of what each property is about.

block2_text.eng: **Same and different:** Make a playful activity out of this by showing your students two objects and asking how they are the same and how they are different. Be prepared for surprising ideas and do include silly suggestions along with the more serious ones.

block3_text.eng: For example, talk about the size or age of a child and an adult – one is younger and the other older, and one is shorter and the other is taller. Or you could talk about a bird and a dog – one can fly and has feathers and the other has fur and cannot fly.

block4_text.eng: If you hand a child a spoon and fork, there are many things the child might say. They are the same because you eat with both of them. They are also the same because you hold both of them, they are about the same size, or they are made of the same material. They are different because one is smooth and somewhat round, while the other is pointed.

block5_text.eng:
A fun activity for practicing with properties is to show your child a small set of objects and ask which of them doesn't belong. Challenge your child to identify the object that is not like the others and to explain why. Accept any reason that makes sense; your child may have an unusual reason.

This has also been called "Find the Spy." The spy is the person who is an outsider pretending to be just like the other three. Discuss which of the four things is the most unusual.

rows.name: Patterns – Introduction

block1_text.eng:
**Patterns are everywhere!:** Recognizing, describing, and creating patterns is central to playing with mathematics. Finding and understanding patterns is a key component of any of the sciences, and more generally analyzing anything you want to understand.

**Not all patterns repeat:** When "patterns" are mentioned, the type of patterns that come to mind are repeating patterns, such as the one with repeating shapes pictured below. However, patterns are any collection of objects that follow a rule. The numbers 2, 4, 6, 8, ... form the familiar pattern of even numbers.

block2_text.eng:
**Repeating Patterns:** These are the patterns that very young children can relate to most easily, and they are the ones we look at now. Here are some characteristics that can be used by themselves or mixed together to create patterns:

* Movement patterns: stepping, jumping, waving, nodding
* Sound patterns: clapping, knee slapping, tongue clicking, stamping
* Loudness patterns: soft, medium, loud
* Visual patterns: color, shape, size, repeating tile patterns

Repeating movement and sound patterns are covered in the next topic.

block3_text.eng: Challenge each other to find repeating patterns wherever you are. You might notice a repeating tile work in a floor, wall, or ceiling. The brick work of a building might make an interesting pattern. Plants may be planted in an organized pattern in a field. The side of a pineapple or pine cone may have a spiral pattern.

block4_text.eng: **Sequence of drawings:** Create puzzles by drawing a pattern of shapes. One person establishes a pattern and then leaves gaps in the repeating sequence for the other to fill in.

rows.name: Movement & Sound Patterns

block1_text.eng:
This is an age for children to be active, so working with patterns of movement and sound is a natural activity. Here is a partial list of these patterns, and of course these can be combined and intermixed.

* Movement patterns: stepping, jumping, waving, nodding, head scratch, ear tug
* Sound patterns: clapping, knee slapping, tongue clicking, stamping, drum hit
* Loudness patterns: soft, medium, loud

block2_text.eng:
Two or more people can challenge each other to repeat and extend each other's patterns. This can be done in many ways. The simplest is for one person to create a pattern of sounds and movements and have all the others repeat it. For example, the pattern might be: clap, clap, stomp, clap, clap, stomp.

Add difficulty to this by having the original person add one more item to the end of the pattern every time the pattern goes once around the group. Alternatively, each person can take the pattern that comes to them and add one more item at the end of it.

block3_text.eng: Create rhythmic music by starting with a pattern on one instrument (perhaps a drum), and then layering patterns on other instruments on top of that. Dance often involves repeating movements to music. Play some simple music that has an obvious beat (perhaps the one the children just created), and then create a pattern of movements to the music.

block4_text.eng: Use patterns as an agreed upon way for being allowed to enter some place such as a room or part of a room. This might be a series of fist bumps and other type of handshakes. Or it might be knocking and stamping that causes a series of sounds.

rows.name: Describing Shapes

block1_text.eng:
**Properties:** Shapes have many properties, some of which are essential to define and identify the shape, and others are incidental. For example, an object might have three flat sides, be red, and be made out of wood. The three flat sides are essential for seeing that it is a triangle.

**Key Properties:** Here are some key ingredients that make up describing, recognizing, and understanding the standard shapes.

block2_text.eng:
There are 2-dimensional shapes that are flat like a piece of paper. Physical models of these shapes are not actually 2-dimensional (they have thickness), but they benefit from being thought of that way. Polygons (e.g. triangles, rectangles, hexagons) and circles are examples of flat shapes.

There are 3-dimensional shapes that have depth and are sometimes described as solid. Boxes, balls, pyramids, and cylinders are examples of solid shapes.

block3_text.eng:
These are flat, 2-dimensional shapes. Faces usually refer to portions of the outside of a 3-dimensional object. For example, a box has 6 faces that are rectangles.

Though most faces will be polygons, sometimes they can be curved. For example, the top and bottom faces of a cylinder are circles.

block4_text.eng: The edges or sides are the straight line segments that form a polygon.

block5_text.eng: For shapes, the individual points of interest will be the ones where two (or more) edges meet. The technical word vertex (vertices) is a bit advanced for this age, but it can be used.

block6_text.eng: Two lines, line segments, or rays, that meet in a point form an angle there.

block7_text.eng: Angles that look like the corner of a piece of paper are called right angles. They are also said to have 90 degrees, but that description should wait until your students can count and understand the numbers up to 100 or 200.

block8_text.eng: Lines and faces can be straight or curved. The sides of a polygon are straight. A circle is curved.

block9_text.eng:
Describing two or more edges as having the same size is important for differentiating different shapes within the same family.

For example, if a triangle has two equal sides it is called isosceles. If a triangle has three equal sides it is equilateral or regular.

block10_text.eng:
**Relative Positions:** Shapes may have positions relative to other shapes. Understanding those describing words is important for describing scenes, and also describing how some shapes are made up of smaller shapes. These are words like: above, over, under, inside, beside, next to, behind, between, and near.

**Example:** The blue mug is on top of the brown shelf, or the brown shelf is under the blue mug.

rows.name: Shape Names – 2D & 3D

block1_text.eng:
**Learn shape names through exposure:** There are a lot of words to learn. However, if you make a habit of exposing children to these words, they will pick them up slowly but surely. Challenge your students to find examples of these shapes in the world around them. Make treasure hunt challenges of finding particularly hard to find shapes.

**Important differentiators:** There are properties that children need to understand to be able to classify and name shapes.

* Counting sides
* Counting angles
* Sides with same length.
* Sides are parallel
* Identifying right angles.

block2_text.eng:
These are the names and brief descriptions of some of the most common 2-dimensional shapes. They are illustrated at the bottom of this text.
* Circle
* Triangle – 3 sides and 3 angles
* Equilateral (or Regular) Triangle – 3 equal sides and angles
* Right Triangle – has a right angle
* Isosceles Triangle – 2 equal sides and 2 equal angles
* Square – 4 equal sides and 4 right angles – it is both a rectangle and a rhombus.
* Rectangle – 4 sides and 4 right angles (all equal of course)
* Rhombus – 4 equal sides and 4 angles – it is also a parallelogram
* Parallelogram – 2 pairs of parallel sides – opposite sides are equal
* Trapezoid (or Trapezium) – 1 pair of parallel sides
* Kite – two pairs of adjacent, equal sides (convex)
* Dart – two pairs of adjacent, equal sides (concave)
* Pentagon – 5 sides and 5 angles
* Hexagon – 6 sides and 6 angles
* Heptagon or Septagon – 7 sides and 7 angles
* Octagon – 8 sides and 8 angles

**Polygons:** Except for the circle, the shapes listed above are all examples of polygons. A polygon with equal sides and equal angles is called a **regular polygon.**

**Size and Orientation:** Although these are shown in standard positions, it is important to vary the size and orientation of these shapes when you display them. If a child always sees a square with its sides going horizontally and vertically, they won't recognize squares when they are rotated and look like diamonds. The same is true for triangles.

block3_text.eng:
There are many 3-dimensional shapes. These are some of the most common ones:
* Ball (Sphere)
* Cylinder (round tube with end caps)
* Cone
* Box (Cube is a special case)
* Pyramid – triangle or square base

In addition to basic questions about these shapes, a good way to practice them is to compare and contrast them – this will be covered in the next topic.

block4_text.eng: Use straws or sticks and stick them together with clay, gum, or some other sticky substance.

rows.name: Compare  & Sort Shapes

block1_text.eng: **Deeper Shape Understanding:** Although mastery of the basic definitions of shapes is an essential starting point, one of the best ways to understand shapes more deeply is to compare, contrast, and sort them.

block2_text.eng:
**Same and Different:** Have a collection of objects, cut out shapes, or shapes on cards, and randomly select two of them – how are they different and how are they the same? 

Ask for all sorts of comparisons. For example, what is similar and different when comparing a circle and a ball?

block3_text.eng: For example, a rectangle and a square have four sides and all right angles, but the sides of a rectangle are not all the same size (though opposite sides are).

block4_text.eng:
For four-sided shapes, which ones are also another kind of shape, and which are not?

**Examples Questions:**
* Are all rectangles squares, or are all squares rectangles?
* Are all squares rhombuses or are all rhombuses squares?
* Are all rectangles rhombuses or are all rhombuses rectangles?
* Are all parallelograms rhombuses, or are all rhombuses parallelograms?

When there is an instance of something not always true, ask for an example. If not all rectangles are squares, please draw an example.

block5_text.eng: **Sorting:** Give your students a collection of shapes or objects and ask them to sort them into things that share at least one property. Let them decide which property to sort on, and then discuss their decision. Have one group do the sorting and another group discover what property they used to sort on.

block6_text.eng: Encourage non-obvious sorting categories. For example, shapes that have right angles or shapes that have no two sides the same length.

block1_text.eng:
The outside surface of a 3-dimensional shape is made up of 2-dimensional shapes. Describing the outside surface of shapes gives great practice with understanding solid shapes. You can practice by taking a solid shape and asking a child to describe its surface. Alternatively, you can give a child a description of the outside surface and ask them which solid shape you are describing.

Here is a list of 3-dimensional figures with descriptions of their outside shapes.

block2_text.eng: This has a single curved surface. If you were to cut the surface along its "equator" you would have two cups which you could flatten down to be two discs.

block3_text.eng: Its ends (bases) are two discs. If you cut its curved side with a straight cut from top to bottom it creates a rectangle.

block4_text.eng: This has 6 faces that are rectangles.

block5_text.eng: This has triangles for the side, and a polygon for the base. Typically the base is a regular polygon. A triangular pyramid has a triangle for its base, and a square pyramid has a square for its base.

block6_text.eng: This has a circle on the bottom. If you slit the curved surface from the point (vertex) to the bottom creates a portion of a disc (a sector).

rows.name: Composing & Decomposing

block1_text.eng:
Explore what shapes are all about by putting shapes together to make new shapes, or taking them apart into smaller shapes. Aid this exploration by cutting out some paper polygons or using pattern blocks if you have them.

**Putting shapes together:** The exploration can be free form, where you challenge a child to create a pretty design or make an image that looks like something. Or, the exploration can be guided by a challenge such as: Take these shapes and use some of them to create a bigger triangle or hexagon. How many ways can you do that?

block2_text.eng: **Breaking shapes up:** You can also create challenges where you take a bigger shape and ask the child to draw in lines that will break the shape into triangles, rectangles, and hexagons (for example).

block3_text.eng:
Breaking up shapes into equal size pieces is good preparation for understanding fractions. When you do this, practice using the words for fractional sizes, such as halves, thirds, fourths (quarters), and so on.

The standard examples are breaking up a circle into equal parts using lines radiating out from the center, and breaking rectangles into smaller rectangles using rows and columns. However, interesting challenges can be created taking other shapes and breaking them into smaller pieces of the same size and shape. 

You can do this same activity with 3-dimensional shapes, but it is a lot trickier to construct regular shapes in this case

rows.name: Tilings

block1_text.eng:
**Definition** A **tiling** (or **tessellation**) of a 2-dimensional surface is a complete covering of it with a set of non-overlapping shapes that has no gaps. Usually, a small collection of shapes is used, and often they are all regular polygons, though a great variety of kinds of shapes may be used.

**Exploring** Theer are many sophisticated things to do with tilings; however, it is wonderful fun for a child to simply fit polygon shapes together and discover the shapes and patterns they create, without any particular end goal in mind. Your students will learn a lot in this unstructured form of play.

If you have access to pattern blocks, these our great for students to use to explore what can be done. If they are not available, use a stiff material such as cardboard, wood, or stiff paper to make poygons where the sides of all the shapes have a single length.

block2_text.eng:
**Challenges** Make this a structured activity by giving your students explicit challenges.
* Make everyday shapes – house, animal, face, tree.
* Find as many ways as possible to create different sizes of a given shape: regular triangles, squares, rectangles, or hexagons.
* Find tilings that have a repeating pattern.
* Find tilings where every corner in the tiling has the same types of polygons in the same pattern surrounding it.

**Regular Polygons** This is a beginning topic, so we will only use regular polygons when looking at more structured forms of tilings.

**Regular Tilings** A **regular tiling** is one that uses one kind of regular polygon. There are three regular tilings, and they use regular triangles, squares, and regular hexagons, as pictured below. These patterns can be found in many buildings that have tiled floors or walls.

block3_text.eng: **Semi-regular and Others** There are a great many categories of tilings. **Semi-regular tilings** use regular polygons and look exactly the same at every corner in the tiling. There are eight of these, as pictured below.

block4_text.eng:
It is a bit advanced for this age group, but you can analyze how the interior angles might potentially fit together for a tiling. Even for older students, this is easier to look at the angles in terms of full turns rather than in degrees.

Here is a chart for the interior angles of a regular polygon with this many sides. The fraction given is the faction of a turn for the interior angle of the polygon.
* 3 – 1/6
* 4 – 1/4
* 5 – 3/10
* 6 – 1/3
* 7 – 5/14
* 8 – 3/8
* 10 – 2/5
* 12 – 5/12

You can use this chart to see why the angles add up correctly for the regular and semi-regular tilings. For example, it takes 6 triangles because each one produces 1/6 of a turn.

rows.name: Reflect, Rotate, Symmetries

block1_text.eng:
**Rigid Motions** A **rigid motion** of the plane is moves points so every figure maintains its shape and size. More technically, it preserves the distance between every pair of points. To study finite figures that have some form of symmetry, we will look at reflections and rotations. We will ignore, for now, the third type of rigid motion, translations, because a figure must be infinite to have translational symmetry.

**Reflections** A **reflection** about a line takes each point and moves it across the line, as in the illustration on the left below. The points in the line are left fixed (unmoved). The line involved in the reflection is called the **line of reflection** or more simply the **mirror line.** The name of reflection comes from what happens when you look in a mirror or dark body of water. One feature of reflections is that they reverse things – for example, the reflection of a drawing of a right hand will become the drawing of a left hand.

**Rotations** A rotation of some turn amount about a point rotates everything that much around the point, as in the illustration on the right. The point being rotated around is left fixed and is called the **center of the rotation.**

block2_text.eng:
**Symmetries** Figures that are moved to themselves by any rigid motion are called **symmetric.** They often have pleasing shapes that children enjoy. Some figures enjoy a single kind of symmetry, while some figures have many kinds.

**Mirror Symmetry** This is the most common kind of symmetry, and it is the type people think of when symmetries are brought up. A figure has a **mirror symmetry,** or briefly it is **symmetric,** if it is moved to itself by a reflection.

**Rotational Symmetry** If a rotation moves a figure to itself, it is said to have some anlge amount of **rotaitonal symmetry.** Note that a figure that has rotational symmetry of some angle amount, will also have rotational symmetry for every multiple of that angle amount.

block3_text.eng:
* A one-headed arrow, ⇒, has a mirror symmetry with the line down the shaft of the arrow.
* A two-headed arrow, ⇔, has mirror symmetries for the line down the shaft and the vertical line halfway between the two points. It also has half-turn (180 degrees) rotational symmetry about the point in the middle of the line.
* A butterfly has mirror symmetry using the line down the middle of its body.
* Regular polygons have many mirror symmetries and rotational symmetries. Regular polygons with an even number of sides have mirror symmetries for the lines between the midpoints of opposite sides and for the lines between opposite vertices. For those with an odd number of sides, there are mirror symmetries for lines connecting a vertex with the midpoint of the opposite side. A regular polygon with n sides has 1/n-turn rotational symmetry about its center (also 2/n, 3/n, 4/n, ...). For example, a regular pentagon has 1/5, 2/5, 3/5 and 4/5-turn rotational symmetries.
* A rectangle has 2 mirror symmetries connecting the midpoints of opposite sides, and 1/2-turn (180 degrees) rotational symmetry about its center.
* A kite has the single mirror symmetry connecting a pair of opposite vertices.

Explore the symmetries you find in other polygons as well as in some of the tiling patterns your students create.

block4_text.eng:
Some interesting things happen if you do one rigid motion followed by another. This is an interesting area to experiment with for a class that is somewhat advanced.

**Two Reflections** If you follow one reflection with another, one of two things will happen. If the two lines of reflection are parallel, then the net effect will be to create a translation. If the two lines intersect, you will get a rotation about the point of intersection.

**Two Rotations With the Same Center** This has the predictable effect of having the amount of rotation being the sum of the two rotations.

**A Translation and a Reflection** This produces the rigid motion called a **glide reflection.**

**Play** Explore what happens with other combinations. Are the results what you expected, or were there some surprises?

rows.name: Quantities & Counting

block1_text.eng: **Surprisingly complicated:** Learning how to count, and relating counting to quantities, has many parts to it. Each part may take a while to be learned and there will be minor missteps along the way. Much of this is developmental and cannot be explicitly taught – instead, there needs to be exposure and practice until it clicks.

block2_text.eng:
* **Unchanging order** The counting sequence is always the same.
* **One-to-one correspondence** Count a collection of objects by putting them in one-to-one correspondence with the numbers being said. The child can touch the objects as they count.
* **The last number is the quantity** When counting a group of objects, the last spoken number is the quantity of objects.
* **Order and rearrangement don’t change the count** The child can count the objects in any order, and the objects can be rearranged, and the count will always be the same.
* **Subgroups of bigger groups have smaller counts**

block3_text.eng:
**Repeating the sequence:** At first, children start by repeating the numbers in sequence. Don't be surprised if they leave out some of the numbers or they say the numbers in the wrong order. If they make errors, don't make a big deal out of it; simply say the count correctly and move on. This is all part of the process and they will eventually learn the numbers in the correct order.

**Count down sometimes:** Counting down helps children understand the sequence. This helps keep it from being a meaningless sequence of sounds. Do this almost any time you would have counted up. For example, if you have three apples you want to remove, count down from three after you take away each apple.

**Include 0 sometimes:** Start counting from 0 sometimes to help 0 become an accepted number and quantity. You can also count down to 0. Counting down to 0 is great for events that are about to happen, say in five seconds. You can count down to 0 and then say "Blastoff" or something similar.

block4_text.eng:
Use number paths and number lines to solidify number order and give a useful visual reference. These start from 0 and increase from left to right. These are helpful for practicing counting, next and previous numbers, and for practicing addition and subtraction.

For number paths, place numbered cards on the ground to walk along, or place cards on a table top, string, or along a ledge. Place number lines on paper or on walls.

block5_text.eng:
Some standard mistakes children make are:

* Leaving out or repeating a number during the sequence
* Counting an object twice or missing an object
* Not realizing to stop counting when all objects have been counted
* Thinking there are more objects when the objects are larger.

When a mistake occurs, demonstrate the right way to do the counting and move on. Don’t treat the errors as remarkable.

block1_text.eng: **Asking for quantities:** Make plenty of opportunities for your students to count out a specific number of things from a collection of objects. If there is a pile of sticks, ask a student to give you three of them. Have them count them one at a time as they hand you a stick or put the sticks in a particular place.

rows.name: Subitizing to 10

block1_text.eng:
**Subitizing is surprisingly important:** The word **subitizing** refers to recognizing a quantity at a glance. This skill is foundational for counting, particularly Counting On, understanding part-whole relationships, adding, and subtracting.

Part of subitizing is becoming used to seeing and understanding a group of objects as a unit, which is called **unitizing.** Practice with subitizing helps develop the unitizing skill, which in turn is important for many parts of mathematics, such as place value.

block2_text.eng: **Unitizing:** This is an important conceptual step for a child. They are learning to treat a group of individual things as a single new thing, which is called unitizing. This is a developmental step that may take a while and cannot be hurried. Practice will of course help develop a sense of how this works.

block3_text.eng: People are born with the ability to instantly recognize quantities of size 1, 2, and 3. With a bit of practice quantities of size 4 or 5 can be added to this list as a child develops a sense for quantities, numbers, and patterned arrangements.

block4_text.eng: As a child becomes familiar with certain patterns of dots, particularly the patterns on dice, those will begin to be instantly recognizable to them.

block5_text.eng: There are two routines in the Instructional Routines section that are particular useful for practicing subitizing and unitizing. Dot Talks using dot cards are simple and quick ways to make recognizing these small quantities automatic. Splat routines are a fun way to start adding a little bit of complexity to Dot Cards.

block6_text.eng: Ten frames have many educational uses. One is to make it easier to learn how to subitize the quantities up to 10 when presented in a standard way in a ten frame.

block7_text.eng: Once certain configurations become familiar, they can be built upon to make it easier to count larger quantities as well as gain confidence with Counting On. In the example above, instead of counting all 7 dots individually, a child may see that there are 5 dots with 2 more, and be able to Count On with "5, 6, 7."

block8_accord.eng: Tip: Five frames are not as useful

block8_text.eng: Surprisingly, despite being like the fingers on one hand and being the upper half of a ten frame, five frames are not as effective at helping children learn to subitize and recognize quantities. With five frames, children have a tendency to continue counting, so they have a much harder time making the leap to subitizing.

rows.name: Comparing up to 10

block1_text.eng: **Compare quantities in lines next to each other:** An easy and compelling way to compare quantities is to put them in two lines, one directly below the other. The shorter line is the smaller quantity and the longer line the larger quantity. As noted below, this works best if the items all have the same size and shape.

block2_text.eng:
**Using the sequence of numbers:** A more abstract way to compare two numbers is to see which one comes before the other in the counting sequence. This is too abstract as an initial way to teach comparison, but if it is frequently associated with the line-em-up method, it will become familiar and understood.

**Use equal quantities sometimes:** Give appropriate amount of time to quantities that are the same so that children do not lose sight of this possibility.

block3_text.eng: **Size may confuse quantity:** A child can quite reasonably see one large stick as being "more sticks" than two small sticks. Avoid this problem by using objects that are all the same size and shape until the concept of quantity is thoroughly understood.

block4_text.eng: Teach the three symbols "<" "=" ">" along with the numerals when doing comparing. Tell the child that the larger quantity goes on the wider side. Some people like to say that the inequality symbol is a hungry alligator, and the open mouth is open towards the larger quantity.

block1_text.eng:
**Everyday use:** Learning the words first, second, third, fourth, fifth, and last is similar to learning the number names – it is just a matter of exposure and practice.

Use these words when discussing daily routines by asking what should be done first, second, and third. Also, ask questions such as "What are the last things to do when you leave a room?" (turn off the lights and close the door)

block2_text.eng: **Putting in order:** Combine the use of these words with putting things in order. A natural set of things to order is a group of numbers. Have a collection of number cards, mix them up, and then ask your students to put them in order. Which one comes first? Which one is last? Which one is next? As the students get better at this task, leave some of the numbers out of the set.

rows.name: Writing Numbers 0 to 10

block1_text.eng:
**Ways to Practice:** Just as with writing the alphabet letters, it will take lots of practice to make reasonably good numerals. It will take time and there is no hurry.

Here are some ideas for ways for practicing writing the numerals from 0 to 9: 

* Cut out numerals made of sandpaper or some other tactile surface. These are excellent for having a child trace with a fingertip to get the flow of each numeral.
* Choose initial ways to practice that make it easy to experiment, and are forgiving of mistakes. For example, have the child practice writing in dirt or sand, where a mistake is easily erased. 
* When the child starts writing on a white board or paper, make dashed or dotted versions of the numerals that they can practice with when writing their first numerals.

block2_text.eng: Mistakes will be frequent at this early age. Even after initial mastery, numerals will sometimes be written reversed or upside down. Handle this calmly by simply writing the numeral correctly nearby and pointing out the difference to the child. These mistakes may persist for quite a while, and it is generally just a sign that the child is waiting to make a developmental step.

block1_text.eng: **Use two ten frames:** As the quantities become larger, it is essential to present them in an organized form that makes them easier to understand. Using ten frames works well, and your students should be used to them by now. For numbers 11 to 20, use two ten frames with a completely filled ten frame next to a partially filled one.

block2_text.eng: **Use bundles of ten:** A good alternative to ten frames is to tie together bundles of ten objects that you want to work with or to use blocks that can be snapped together in grouops of ten.

block3_text.eng: The numbers from 11 to 20 in English are not as easy to learn as they should be. The two numbers 11 and 12 are particularly unusual. It would be so much easier if the numbers were named "ten and one" and "ten and two," as they are in some languages. Similarly, 20 would be much easier as "two tens." This lack of logical naming means that many of the numbers from 11 to 20 will need to be learned by exposure and practice, just as the numbers 0 to 10 were.

rows.name: Place Value to 20

block1_text.eng:
**Tens and Ones** In general, two-digit quantities and numbers are understood in terms of tens and ones. In the topic "Quantities and Counting to 20," we used two ten frames, or made use of bundles of ten, to organize the counting and to make the quantities easier to understand. 

**Expanded notation:** Expanded Notation does the same thing for written numbers. It is handy to introduce it now for understanding numbers between 10 and 20, and it will become an essential tool for breaking apart and understanding numbers above 100.

**Examples:** Expanded notation takes the contribution of each digit of a number, isolates it, and understands it in terms of its place value.
* In 17, the one represents 10, so expand 17 as 10 + 7. 
* Similarly, 276 expands to 200 + 70 + 6.

Expanded notation is extremely useful for learning arithmetic operations with multi-digit numbers. This will be an important tool and it should be developed fully and practiced thoroughly.

rows.name: Comparing to 20

block1_text.eng: **Bigger or Smaller than 10:** For numbers from 0 to 20, the first step is to compare the two numbers to 10. Use ten frames or bundles to show that any number from 0 to 9 will be less than any number from 10 to 20. If both numbers are between 10 and 20, show that the amount each number is greater than 10 will decide which number is larger.

block2_text.eng:
**Compare tens first in two-digit numbers:** Emphasize that comparing numbers from 0 to 20 is done by looking first at whether they are between 0 and 10 or between 10 and 20. This mindset, that the tens digit is of primary importance, will serve them well when they start comparing all two-digit numbers.

**Rule** For comparing two-digit numbers in general, compare the tens digit first and then the ones digit.

block3_text.eng:
**Different tens:** 5 < 12 because any number in the 0s will be less than any number in the 10s.

**Same tens:** 15 < 17 because both numbers are in the 10s, so you only need to compare 5 and 7.

block1_text.eng:
**Counting:** You have already covered the numbers to 20, and that is the hard part. From 20 onward the main new thing is learning the names for the tens.

**100 Chart:** Use a 100 chart to help practice the names of the tens and to help see where the numbers are located in the sequence. Skip count by 10s and point to the 10s column on the 100 chart.

block2_text.eng:
**Bundles of 10 and Place Value:** Using ten frames for numbers above 30 can be cumbersome. Create many bundles of ten (e.g. blocks or sticks) that you can use to explain ideas and for the children to experience the groups of ten. Practice taking a number, such as 35, and representing it as 3 bundles of ten and 5 single items. 

Have students count up (or down) and add (or remove) a block or stick with each number. When counting up, each time a group of ten items is formed, swap that group with a pre-made bundle of ten. When counting down, each time you run out of individual items, swap one of the bundles of ten for a group of ten items. 

As the first big exposure to place value and to unitizing groups of ten, this should be practiced until it feels completely natural and automatic.

**Expanded Notation:** Build on the foundation for expanded notation that you developed for numbers up to 20. Once your children are comfortable thinking of the numbers to 100 as some number of bundles of 10 please some singletons, transfer that knowledge to their written work. Take a written number, such as 35, and rewrite it as 30 + 5, and say that this is writing 35 as 3 bundles of 10 with 5 left over.

block3_text.eng:
**Practice Counting Downward as well as Upward:** A student who can count up to 100 easily and quickly can sometimes have trouble counting downwards. Such a student has learned to repeat the words, but they have not absorbed the meaning. 

Counting downward forces them to become more aware of what is actually happening with the numbers. The tricky spots are crossing some number of tens, and those are the areas that need the most practice and reinforcement. For example, counting 62, 61, 60, 59, 58.

rows.name: Comparing to 100

block1_text.eng: **Use Bundles:** Compare quantities by lining up the bundles of ten and then placing the singletons after them. After much experimentation, your students should extend the rule they already have for comparing numbers up to 20. Have them discover that if one number has fewer bundles of ten than the other, then it must be smaller no matter how the singletons match up; and if the numbers have the same number of bundles of ten (such as 47 and 44 below), then the singletons determine which one is smaller.

block2_text.eng:
**The Rule for Comparing Numbers to 100:** 
* If one number has fewer tens, then it is smaller.
* If the two numbers have the same number of tens, then the singletons determine the comparison.

**Use Expanded Notation:** After much experience with quantities and bundles, translate that experience to using expanded notation and regular numbers. 

**Examples:**
* 35 > 28. Show 30 + 5 > 20 + 8 and say that no number in the 20s can be as big as a number in the 30s. 
* 46 > 42. Show 40 + 6 > 40 + 2 and say that the 6 > 2 compels 46 > 42.

rows.name: Quantities for Add & Subtract

block1_text.eng: Counting a group of objects develops a connection between counting and quantities. Similarly, use counting two groups of objects to make addition and subtraction tangible.

block2_text.eng: **Addition:** Have a group of 3 objects and a group of 2 objects. Count the 3 objects and the 2 objects separately. Then talk about what happens when you put the two groups together, that 3 objects plus 2 objects is 5 objects altogether.

block3_text.eng: **Transition to Counting On:** As a student gets comfortable with seeing a set number of objects, such as 2, 3, 4, or 5 of them, use that familiarity to practice adding with Counting On. When you have 3 objects and 2 objects, instead of counting “1, 2, 3, 4, 5” you can point at the 3 objects and say “3,” and then continue the counting to include the 2 objects with “4, 5.”

block4_text.eng:
**2 Subtraction Models** Subtraction should be modeled as both “take away” and as “difference.”.

**Take away:** Start with 5 objects, count them, and then take 2 away as you count “1, 2.” Count that there are 3 objects remaining. Do this by counting down from 5 and keeping track of how many have been removed on your fingers: “5” (no fingers), “4” (1 finger), “3” (2 fingers).

block5_text.eng: **Difference:** Put 2 objects above 5 objects and count how many more objects the group of 5 has. You are finding how far apart they are, which is their difference. You can do this by Counting On from 2 and keeping track of the difference on your fingers: “2” (no fingers), “3” (1 finger), … “5” (3 fingers).

block6_text.eng:
A number line on a wall, or a number path, are useful environments for practicing adding and subtracting.

**Addition:** On a number path, have the student start at 0 and then walk forward for the count of the first number. After that, have them walk forward counting out the second number. They are standing on the sum of the two numbers.

There are two ways to do subtraction on a number path. Let's use 7 - 3 as an example.

**Take away:** Have a student stand at 7 and then walk back three steps to end on the 4.

**Difference:** Have one student stand on 7 and another on 3, and then ask how many steps are between them.

block7_accord.eng: Tip: Fingers are a good manipulative

block7_text.eng:
Fingers are a convenient set of objects to count for these small problems. One lovely thing about fingers is they are always available.

**Addition:** Take 3 fingers on one hand and 2 fingers on another, then move the two hands together and count the 5 fingers.

**Take away:** For 7 - 3, first put up 7 fingers and then count to 3 as you lower one finger at a time.

**Difference:** For 7 - 3, first put up 3 fingers and then count "1, 2, 3, 4" as you raise one finger at a time until 7 fingers are raised.

rows.name: Add & Subtract 1, 2

block1_text.eng:
The ideas of One More and One Less are foundational steps for adding and subtracting.

**Next and Previous:** One more and One Less are strongly connected to the ideas of the “next number” and “previous number” when you are counting up and down. Counting practice in both directions will help a child recognize which number comes next and which number was the previous one.

block2_text.eng: **2 more or less** When your students are ready, extend their understanding to what happens when you have “two more” or “two less.” There is no hurry to get to this, so please make sure they thoroughly understand one more and one less first. If using two is very easy for them to visualize, you can extend this to three.

block3_text.eng:
**Subtracting 1 or 2 Apart** To perform One Less or Two Less, your students should naturally use the "take away" model for subtraction. To subtract numbers that are near to each other, use the "difference" model. By this point, these small distances should be easy to visualize on a number path or line.

For example, to do 7 – 5, see that the numbers are 2 apart. This calculation is much harder to do using the take away model.

block4_text.eng:
Gradually combine these ideas with “adding” and “subtracting” by asking questions such as: "How many pebbles do you have now? If I add 1 more, how many would you have? If I took 1 away so you had 1 less, how many would you have?"

These are easy and natural questions to fit into everyday conversation, and your students can talk about them without noticing at first that they are doing addition and subtraction.

block5_text.eng:
If you have 3 of something and your students have four of that thing, you can discuss various possibilities.
* Would you have the same amount if you had one more?
* Would you have the same amount if your child has one less. Be playful with the idea. 

If your numbers are 3 and 5, you can talk about getting one more twice, or about one of you getting one more and the other getting one less.

block6_text.eng: With this simple bit of arithmetic, you can start playing some of the games with adding and subtracting. A simple one is the game of Nim with 1 and 2, using either addition or subtraction. Other games are Get Out of My House and Within 1 or 2

rows.name: Add & Subtract within 5

block1_text.eng:
**Counting On:** Your students have been doing adding problems by counting each individual item. If asked to add two things to three things, that was done by counting all five things. As they master Counting On, some of that counting is replaced by starting with one of the numbers, say 3 in this example, and then counting the two remaining things (“4, 5”). This experience with counting also allows a child to visualize and master the ideas of 1 more and 2 more, which has made adding 1 and 2 much easier.

**Zero is Important:** Mix in adding 0 sometimes. It is easy to do, and it is important conceptually. Similarly, mix in questions where you subtract 0 and questions where you subtract everything. For example, if you have three bits of food and you eat all of them, how many do you have left?

block2_text.eng: Start using ten frames to provide a structured environment for learning these math facts, as well as to lead into learning number bonds. Play up the connection of ten frames with having ten fingers on two hands.

block3_text.eng: Start using “+” and “–” and “=” when you write down this material for your children. Also, don’t always write equalities with the “result” on the right. Writing “=” just means that the two sides are equal, not that the left side produces the right side. So,  5 – 1 = 4, 3 = 5 – 2,  and 1 + 3 = 5 – 1 are all good things to write and should be intermixed.

block4_text.eng:
Children of this age benefit greatly from having manipulatives to use when doing addition and subtraction. It cements their understanding of the numbers in terms of quantities.

The manipulative that is always available is their fingers. When doing the example of adding two to three, they can put up two fingers on one hand, three fingers on the other hand, and bring the two hands together. Another way to do it is to raise two fingers on one hand, raise three more fingers on that same hand, and then see a total of five fingers raised.

The ideas behind practicing subtraction are similar to those for addition. If your child is going to subtract three from five, have your chid raise five fingers and then lower three of them. Their familiarity with one less and two less will probably make subtracting one and two very easy.

block5_text.eng: As your student does various adding and subtracting problems, your child will become more and more familiar with them and will eventually memorize them. While it is desirable to eventually make the recall of these facts automatic and easy, there is no hurry.

block6_text.eng: During this time your student's exposure to adding won't be restricted to those whose sum is 5 or less, and that is fine. For example, your student will probably have learned to add 1 or 2 to all the numbers up to 10. Your child may also have begun to learn the doubles facts, such as 3 + 3 or 4 + 4.

rows.name: Doubles

block1_text.eng: **Doubles** are when you add a number to itself, thereby doubling it. Children generally enjoy doubles, so these facts are easily learned and make a good part of a foundation for learning all the single-digit addition facts.

block2_text.eng: Put out two rows of dots or objects and count them. Count them by 2’s sometimes to get the child used to skip counting by 2’s.

block3_text.eng: When talking about adding two 3’s, it is easy and natural to slip into calling it “doubling 3” or “having two 3’s” and eventually “multiplying 2 by 3.” This small adjustment in wording gives exposure and helps make the journey into multiplication feel natural.

block4_text.eng:
Look at the numbers that result from doubles. These are exactly the numbers that can be split into two equal whole parts – e.g. 6 is 3 + 3. These are the even numbers. Numbers that cannot be split into two equal whole parts are the odd numbers. 

Children relate to this splitting naturally if you describe it in terms of doing fair sharing of some resource (food, toys, stones) among two people.

rows.name: Near Doubles

block1_text.eng: This topic combines doubles with the idea of adding and subtracting one. This mental juggling may take some getting used to for some children, and they may resist using this method – and that is okay.

block2_text.eng: For 3 + 4, lay out a row of 3 things above a row of 4 things. Cover over the last of the four things and say that 3 + 3 is 6 – then uncover the last item and say that adding one more is 7. Summarize by saying 3 + 4 is 7. With practice, this can become automatic.

block3_text.eng: 3 + 4 can also be thought of as one less than 4 + 4. For example, with two rows of 4 things, the sum is 8, but then when you take 1 away you get 7 is 3 + 4.

rows.name: Addition Commutes

block1_text.eng: **Order of Addition Makes no Difference:** Consider the two groups of dots below. It does not matter whether you take the three dots on the left and add two more dots to get five dots, or whether you take the two dots on the right and add the three dots on the left to get five dots. Either way, there is a total of five dots!

block2_text.eng:
It is not important for small children to learn the words "commute" and "commutativity." However, it is important that they realize that changing the order does not change the result.

* This saves them learning 3 + 6 once they know 6 + 3.
* It allows them to do addition by Counting On from the larger number.
* It allows an important contrast with subtraction, which does not commute.

block3_text.eng: To remember the word "commute," you can mention that they it is akin to people commuting to work – they are traveling around. The numbers travel around without any problem, so that 2 + 3 is the same as 3 + 2.

rows.name: Number Bonds & Fact Families

block1_text.eng:
Seeing a whole thing as being made up of its parts is an important developmental step for a child. This is the **part-whole concept,** and it can take time.

The **number bonds** for a number, say 6, are all pairs of numbers that add up to 6. It is all the ways of taking the whole of 6 and breaking it into two parts. This reinforces an understanding of the connection between addition and subtraction in forming groups of fact families

The number bonds for 6 are: 0 + 6, 1 + 5, 2 + 4, and 3 + 3. A child who has learned these well will then have little trouble answering the question: "What do I need to add to 2 to get 6?" They will know that 2 + 4 is a number bond for 6, so 4 is the part of 6 that is missing. This strengthens seeing 4 + 2 = 6, 2 + 4 = 6, 6 – 2 = 4, and 6 – 4 = 2 as a family of facts that are tied together.

block2_text.eng: **Addition Commutes:** If you haven’t done so already, start pointing out that addition is commutative, that 2 + 4 = 4 + 2. This aligns nicely with the idea of a fact family.

block3_text.eng: Fluency with number bonds for all numbers up to about 10 is very useful for doing adding and subtracting, The number bonds that arise most often are those for 10. Ten frames are designed to help visualize number bonds for 10. A ten frame with 7 dots in it makes it visually obvious that 7 + 3 is a number bond for 10.

block4_text.eng: Your child should be comfortable counting to 20.

block5_text.eng: Resources (Games): There are quite a few games and puzzles that involve number bonds. Sum Groups is a puzzle designed to practice number bonds. Many games, such as Memory Challenge and Go Fish, have versions that use target totals and thereby exercise number bonds.

block6_text.eng: Play Splat! Activities. Have some objects covered and some uncovered. Tell how many there are altogether and ask how many are covered. There are lots of variations of this.

rows.name: Place Value to 19

block1_text.eng:
Use a bundle of 10 or a ten frame to help your child see the 10 as a unit and be able to reason with it. This is called **unitizing** the 10. The ability to consider a group of 10 as one thing is a surprisingly big step. 

Do lots of practice counting out quantities of objects between 10 and 19 and seeing how a group of 10 objects can be split off. Also frequently represent these numbers in expanded form, as 10 plus some more.

block2_text.eng: **Tip:** Use a filled in ten frame plus a partially filled in ten frame as one way to show these numbers.

block3_text.eng: At these early stages, do not use a coin to represent ten things. This is too abstract a representation at this point.

rows.name: Addition with Fingers

block1_text.eng:

block2_text.eng:

Have your students make a closed fist and say '8.' Then, lift one more finger each time as your students count out loud '9, 10, 11.' When 3 fingers are raised, you are done adding 3, and the counting stops. At that point, you have that 8 plus 3, which is 11.

block3_text.eng: With practice and further number relationship ideas, these math facts will become automatic for your child. rows.name: Subtraction with Fingers

block1_text.eng:
**Two methods:** Subtraction can be thought of as **Take away** or **Difference.** Both models are essential to a complete understanding of subtraction. Have your students practice both ways of thinking of subtraction using these finger subtraction methods.

We’ll use 11 - 3 for our examples.

block2_text.eng:
**Take Away method:** Start with a closed fist and say “11.” Then, lifting one more finger each time, count “10, 9, 8.” Each time you lift a finger and Count Down, you are taking one more away from the original number.

When your students see 3 fingers raised, the counting stops. They now see that taking 3 away from 11 leaves 8.

block3_text.eng:
**Difference method:** This uses Counting On, much as we did for Finger Addition. What we are doing is finding out which number we need to add to 3 to get 11.

Have your students make a closed fist and say “3.” Then, lifting one more finger each time, count “4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11.” When your students say 11, there are 8 fingers raised. That shows that the difference between 3 and 11 is 8!

rows.name: Add & Subtract within 10

block1_text.eng:

* 1. adding and subtracting 1 and 2
* 2. doubles 
* 3. near doubles
* 4. combinations for 10

rows.name: 10 as Bridge – Adding

block1_text.eng:
**Compensation** simplifies addition and subtraction calculations of all sizes. Understanding it also increases number sense for addition and subtraction. It is simpler than it sounds.

The idea is to give or take some small amount to make one of the numbers easier to work with. We will typically be making one of the numbers into a multiple of 10 – the earlier practice with number bonds for 10 pays off here. Suppose you are adding 8 + 7. The 8 just needs 2 more to become 10, so take that 2 away from the 7. This turns 8 + 7 into 10 + 5, which is easy. We could also have done this problem by giving 3 to the 7 to make it 10. In that case, we'd turn 8 + 7 into 5 + 10.

block2_text.eng: **10 as a Bridge:** Single-digit compensation can also be thought of as using 10 as a bridge or intermediate stopping point. Although equivalent to the compensation model, this model may resonate better with some children. When adding 7 to 8, it takes 2 of the 7 to get from 8 to 10, and then there are 5 more left from the 7 to take 10 to 15.

block3_text.eng: With their emphasis on units of 10, ten frames provide a compelling presentation of how to adjust an addition problem to make use of 10. Here compensation is used to change 8 + 7 into 10 + 5.

block4_text.eng: There are often other possibilities for using compensation in a given addition problem. Consider 6 + 8 for example. The 6 could give 2 to the 8 to make this problem 4 + 10. However, the 8 could give 1 to the 6 to make this 7 + 7, a double. Challenge each other to think of different ways for doing a given adding problem.

rows.name: 10 as Bridge – Subtracting

block1_text.eng:
**Compensation:** Add the same amount or subtract the same amount from both numbers. This will keep the distance between the two numbers the same, but can make them easier to work with. Typically that will mean turning the number we're subtracting in the original problem into a multiple of 10. 

**Example:** Suppose we are subtracting 13 – 8. If we add 2 to both numbers, then the distance between them stays the same, but now we are subtracting 15 – 10. Similarly, if we were asked to do 17 – 13, we could subtract 3 from both numbers and turn it into 14 – 10. Alternatively, we could subtract 10 from both numbers and turn it into 7 – 3.

block2_text.eng:
**10 as a Bridge:** Just as we did for addition, we can use 10 as a bridge subtraction problems. Your child should have a strong command of the number bonds for 10 to take full advantage of these methods.

Let's use 12 – 7 as our example. We can do this as a take away or a difference problem.

As a take away problem, we'll use 2 of the 7 to get 12 down to 10. We then have 5 of the 7 left to take the 10 down to 5. We broke 7 into 2 and 5 to be able to use 10 as a bridge along the way.

block3_text.eng: As a difference problem, the total distance between 12 and 7 is the distance between 12 and 10 plus the distance between 10 and 7. The distance between 12 and 10 is 2, and the distance from 10 and 7 is 3, so the total distance is 2 plus 3, which is 5.

block4_text.eng: With their emphasis on units of 10, ten frames provide a compelling presentation of how to adjust a subtraction problem to make use of 10. Here 7 dots are being removed from the 13 dots by breaking 7 into 3 and 4.

rows.name: All 1-digit Add Sub

block1_text.eng:

* Adding and Subtracting within 10
* Adding 10 to single-digit numbers
* Subtracting 10 from 11 to 19
* Using 10 as a bridge for Addition and Subtraction
* Understanding Compensation as a way to transform problems into easier ones

It is okay if your students are still using their fingers for much of this. This should go away as they practice the ideas listed above.

rows.name: Add & Sub 2-Digit & 1-Digit

block1_text.eng:
This starts with the practice you have already done with adding and subtracting with single-digit numbers. When that addition or subtraction leads to a change in the number of tens, the only difference now is that there are more tens involved.

Viewing 10 as a bridge for single-digit addition and subtraction will make your students more comfortable using other multiples of 10 as a bridge.

As with all two-digit operations, this benefits from doing plenty of practice using bundles of ten or with expanded notation. Start with the bundles of ten and then transition to expanded notation as the bundling method becomes intuitive.

**Example:** Adding 7 to 6 causes the number of tens to increase by 1 and the answer is 13. Similarly, adding 7 to 36 causes the tens to increase from 3 to 4, so the answer is 43. 

36 + 7 = 
30 + (6 + 7) =
30 + 13 =
30 + 10 + 3 =
43

block2_text.eng:
**Example:** Subtracting 8 from 12 causes the number of tens to decrease by 1 and the answer is 4. Similarly, subtracting 8 from 32 causes the tens to decrease by 1 and the answer is 24.

32 - 8 =
(20 + 10 + 2) - 8 =
20 + (12 - 8) =
24

block3_text.eng:
**Horizontal promotes better understanding:** You will find that if you initially write these problems horizontally, that it encourages more engagement with what is going on with the tens, and thereby deepens the understanding.

Writing a problem as:

 36
\+ 7

encourages the automatic use of carry marks without knowing what they mean.

Wrting the problem as:

36 + 7

makes it easier to write directly below it things like:

30 + 6 + 7
30 + 13
30 + 10 + 3

This is only needed at first while your students are gaining a thorough understanding of what is going on.

block4_text.eng:
One aspect of these problems that can comfort uneasy students is that they can count up or down to perform the calculation.

Skip counting up or down starting from arbitrary points is a great way to practice these skills.

rows.name: Doubling as Mult.

block1_text.eng: **Gentle Introduction to Multiplication:** Children enjoy adding a number to itself, and it's easy and natural to refer to this as both doubling and as taking two of the number. Once you start referring to "two threes" or "two fives," you are beginning a gentle introduction to the vocabulary and ideas of multiplication.

block2_text.eng:
**Add Depth** After doubling becomes familiar and natural, you can add some depth to the topic in these two ways.

**1. Skip Count by 2's:** With two lines of objects lined up, as in the illustration above, you can count them two at a time. This will be a good introduction to skip counting. If you are counting two rows of three, you can either say "2, 4, 6" or start at 0 sometimes and say "0, 2, 4, 6."

**2. Halves; and Even and Odd Numbers:** When looking at doubles of things, it is also natural to consider splitting collections in half. This is especially easy to see if the there are two equal rows (as in the illustrations above) – this makes it clear that half of a double is just the original number. These are the **even numbers,** the ones that can be shared equally and evenly between two people. The **odd numbers** are the numbers that do not split evenly, as in the illustrations below.

block1_text.eng:

block1_text.eng:
**Groups Of** Understand that the multiplication sign means a number of groups of equal size. You can initially describe this as a brief and clearer way to write repeated addtion. Would you rather see and make sense of 4 + 4 + 4 + 4 + 4 + 4 + 4 or 7 x 4 (7 groups of 4)?

**Many Representations:** There are many representations for multiplication, and they each have important uses. We'll use 3 times 4 as an example throughout.

**Repeated Addition:** When you have three fours, you have 4 + 4 + 4. 

**Equal-sized Groups:** This is similar to repeated addition. You present three identical things, perhaps bags, with four items in each bag.

block2_text.eng: **Rows of Dots:** This example has three groups of four, but now they are aligned in neat, equal rows. This will make it easier to see the structure, and it will also make it easier to see commutativity described in the next step.

block3_text.eng: **Rectangle Areas:** Breaking a rectangle into individual squares introduces the area of a rectangle and provides a good representation for multiplication. For example, if a rectangle is 3 by 4, then break it up into 3 rows of four squares, giving an area that is 3 x 4 squares.
